job_title: Analyst in New York, NY

Decisions are often made behind closed doors with little to no explanations.

job_title: International Credential Evaluator in New York, NY
pros: There are no good resons to work at WES except you will meet nice people and you will value what you had before
cons:
At first you will be fascinated about the workplace and how nice is everyone; but wait ITS HELL. very very arrogant management due to extremely poor experience. and anyone who been there for more than three years will ostentatiously show that they caught an error you did, and you can imagine how it will look like since its open office environment. This org. is ruled only by three seniors and their puppies. The system they use have ALOT of defects although your performance evaluation is strongly based on it. Also you are not allowed to ask question regarding evaluations, for example alot of countries credentials are prorated when a lot of Asian credentials are not because there are managers are originally from those countries "HOPE YOU GOT IT"
My advice do not work there unless you are oriented to work blindly as slave and ready to jump from the window if they ask you to do so, The policy there is "DO NOT ASK, DO NOT TELL".
Also deep leak of transparency, everything done in close door meeting rooms, promotions/rises/bonuses are up to the three persons who run the org. to decide regardless of your hard work. Everything in WES is confidential and vexatiously monitored; you will feel you have been hired to be terminated

job_title: Credential Evaluator in New York, NY
pros: Somewhat stable, as long as you don't keep making big mistakes. Insurance and dental.
cons: Management don't know what they're doing. Every decision is made behind closed doors and the majority of the employees are never included in these discussions. You're making below new york average salary yet you feel you have as much work-life balance as someone who works in a Wall St law firm - every day is exhausting, and not in a good way. They don't talk to you like human beings and they don't treat you with respect. In this place, it is everybody for himself. Everyone is complaining, and at least one person quits every month...

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Flexible work schedule, good location.
cons:
Dirty politics. Rude, aggressive, condescending managers who make you feel like an idiot. Heavy bureaucracy,  upper management are shady.  Some departments are constantly short-staffed because upper management do not believe we were doing our best and everyone is constantly feeling extremely stressed and exploited, and salary is very low. 
The CEO had a habit of finding scapegoats and sacking them to cover up her own mistakes. Half of the company's revenue was transferred to a very questionable external charity fund that is closely connected to the CEO herself.
HR has too much power over important decisions.

review_title: Only stay here for about a year

cons: It is nearly impossible to get ahead at this company. The top people make all the decisions and do not encourage input from employees. There is not much transparency between senor management and staff

review_title: Organization that struggles to manage changing environment/ fast growth.
job_title: Group Manager in New York, NY
pros: A diverse and knowledgeable staff that is hard-working and (on average) faithful to basic work principles.
cons: Lack of transparency. Slow acknowledgment and /or addressing of general issues. Not optimal leadership in some departments. Lack of sense of trust and/or some micromanagement that discourages trust development. Lack of team culture at mid-management.

review_title: What is a review headline??? I'd suggest you have some instructions on how to answer these questions.
job_title: Credential Evaluator in New York, NY
pros: It's great place to work if you're a fresh graduate from a college. I'd say that the salary is too low though.
cons: There's no much career advancement for experienced people. The management is knowledgeable, however, ideas or suggestions offered by evaluators generally are not taken into consideration.

review_title: If you like really exclusive work environments, this is the place for you!!! (Sorry for the long-winded review)
job_title: Administrative Assistant (PKD) in New York, NY
pros: Culturally diverse work environment, nice kitchens, some of the staff was welcoming/friendly. Some of my team members were very resourceful. Current CEO is very friendly and genuine, and takes the time to speak to you when she sees you. Decent Benefits as well.
cons:
The overall environment of the workplace can be characterized as high strung and uncomfortable. 

First off, the training for this position was not organized in any type of manner. Was provided with extremely long, dry, and dense powerpoint slides to read off of, much of which did not even pertain to my job role.  Much of the software they use is exclusive to their company and it is very difficult to learn; it could take weeks for you to learn how to use them. Employees RE also expected to immediately catch on to workplace lingo. There is overwhelmingly too  much unfamiliar terminology that is used in one place. It felt as if they were speaking their own language; most of the acronyms they use aren't even used in the real world. 

Secondly, some of the details in the job description were not clearly explained prior to starting the job. Initially,  wasn't clearly made aware of which departmental trainings I was supposed to assist in facilitating, which resulted in me missing a a few of them. With that said, it was difficult to fully understand the purpose of the job role if you are expected to be at two or more places at one time. 

Thirdly, the supervisor lacked in sufficient communication. After missing the couple of departmental trainings during my training period, 

Fourthly, the environment felt uncomfortable because some of the staff's insubordinate behavior. HR employees are backstabbers as well.  Even after I  left, there was still animosity from employees as well. 

In closing, for this being my first ever full-time job, right after graduating from a four year institution, was a hostile work environment. No one should walk into work every single day dreading to work somewhere, where it's known that some of the employees are doing/saying underhanded things about you. I  regret not saying anything to hold these people accountable, at the same token, I did everything in my power to remain professional and mature to the very end. Another issue is the cliquiness. It was difficult to fit in with the majority of employees because there were numerous cliques and new employees such as myself felt outcasted. I honestly felt as if I was in high school all over again. I think the catty underhanded behavior that I mentioned previously was highly unprofessional and set a bad precedence for me as a new employee. I must say that I am beyond relieved that I left this unfit company. I  wish for whoever  takes on any other position at WES, is highly cognizant of the company culture, environment, and deceitful actions of some of the employees.

review_title: Staff is treated like filth (so sad)
job_title: Evaluator in New York, NY
pros:
Paid time off rolls over year to year.

Diverse workplace.
cons: You know when I first started I loved it here. You learn a lot about other countries and help the applicants we serve. Now it's totally different. There is no respect for staff in evaluations which is the heart of the business. Things are getting worse and worse. It's all about how to degrade and humiliate people. The company's culture is awful because HR doesn't care about staff what-so-ever. Our manager is horrible to people which HR covers up. They now came up with a new production model to increase the quota even more which puts even more pressure on us. I would have to skip my lunch to make it which they say is illegal. It's not worth it anymore.  So many people feel demoralized. I think WES went one step too far with this. There are so many problems that aren't fixed but now it's getting unbearable. They make us do these surveys but don't do anything about the results. They know it's bad but they don't care. Without my team lead I wouldn't have lasted long. The company puts enormous pressure on us when our software hasn't worked properly in 2 months. I was hoping the new CEO would help turn things around but it seems she doesn't really care about employees and that's crushing. I still think she's a nice person though and wish her well. I know I'm not alone. Many people are searching for new employment as I write this. Most of us are young so we can bounce back easily.
